title: How to Ombre Dye Easter Eggs

steps.headline: Hard boil some white eggs.
steps.description: Hallow or blown-out eggs are not recommended for this method because they will float; the eggs need to sit submerged in the dye.

steps.headline: Prepare your dye.
steps.description: Fill a measuring cup with ½ cup (120 milliliters) of boiling water. Stir in 1 teaspoon vinegar and 40 drops food coloring. You can also use an Easter egg dye kit from the store. Dissolve the color tablet in 1 to 2 tablespoons (15 to 30 milliliters) of vinegar. This will be your darkest shade and you will be adding water later.

steps.headline: Place the egg into a cup.
steps.description: Lean the egg against the side of the cup so that it stands upright. If it keeps tipping over, set it down onto a bottle cap. You can also set it into a wire egg holder, then hook the handle over the rim of the cup. If you are using a dye kit, place the egg right into the dye instead. Only the bottom part of the egg should be in the dye.

steps.headline: Pour some dye into the glass and wait 5 minutes.
steps.description: You want the bottom inch (2.54 centimeters) or so of the egg to be submerged. This will create the bottom, darkest layer. If you are using a dye kit, let the egg sit for 30 to 45 seconds.

steps.headline: Add some more dye, then wait 3 minutes.
steps.description: Pour enough dye into the cup so that the bottom third or so of the egg is submerged. Wait 3 minutes. If you are using a dye kit, add some water, then wait 30 to 45 seconds.

steps.headline: Add more dye, then wait 2 minutes.
steps.description: This time, add just enough dye until the bottom two-thirds of the egg is submerged. This should be your lightest shade, or close to it. If you are using a dye kit, add more water, then wait another 30 to 45 seconds.

steps.headline: Decide whether you want the top white or colored.
steps.description: If you want the top white, proceed to the next step. If you want the top colored, pour the rest of the dye into the cup so that the egg is completely covered. Wait 30 to 60 seconds. If you are using a dye kit, cover the egg with water, then let it sit for 30 to 45 seconds more.

steps.headline: Lift the egg out.
steps.description: Use a wire egg holder or a pair of tongs to lift the egg out of the dye bath. Hold it over the cup and let any excess dye drip down.

steps.headline: Let the egg dry.
steps.description: Set the egg down onto a paper towel, an egg holder, or an egg carton. Let the egg dry before adding it to your Easter basket.

steps.headline: Hard boil some white eggs.
steps.description: This method is recommended for hard boiled eggs. If you only have hallow or blown-out eggs on hand, you can try using them. You might want to cover up the holes with paper clay or speckling, however.

steps.headline: Prepare your dye baths.
steps.description: Fill a small cup with ½ cup (120 milliliters) of boiling water. Stir in 1 teaspoon of vinegar and 20 to 40 drops of food coloring. Repeat this step two more times with two different colors. Use colors that are related to each other, such as: red, orange, yellow. Think about how the colors will mix together. If you use contrasting colors, you'll get brown.

steps.headline: Dip your egg into the lightest color.
steps.description: Make sure that the egg is completely submerged. If you can't decide which color is the lightest, choose a primary color instead.

steps.headline: Let the egg sit until you get the shade you want.
steps.description: This will take about 2 to 5 minutes. The longer you let the egg sit, the darker it will become.

steps.headline: Take the egg out of the dye and let it dry.
steps.description: Use a wire egg holder or a pair of tongs to lift the egg out of the dye bath. Set the egg down onto an egg holder or egg carton. Let it dry completely before moving on.

steps.headline: Dip the egg into your next color.
steps.description: This time, dip the egg only two-thirds of the way. The color may change slightly on the egg, because it will be going on top of the first color. For example, if your first color was yellow and your second color was blue, you might get green.

steps.headline: Let the egg sit in the dye before lifting it out.
steps.description: You will need to keep the egg in the dye for a few minutes, or it won't be dark enough. Try to hold the egg steady during this time. If your arm gets tired, you could try setting the egg into a wire egg holder, then looping the handle over the rim of the cup.

steps.headline: Let the egg dry completely before dipping it into your last color.
steps.description: This time, dip only the bottom one-third of the egg into the dye. Once again, hold it there for a few minutes. Depending on the colors you used, the third color may show up true to its shade.

steps.headline: Lift the egg out and let it dry.
steps.description: Once the bottom is the color you want, take the egg out of the dye and set it down onto an egg holder or carton. Let it dry completely.

steps.headline: Hard boil some white eggs.
steps.description: You can try using hallow or blown-out eggs eggs, but be sure to cover the holes with some paper clay or speckling first.

steps.headline: Set the egg down onto an egg holder.
steps.description: You can also use a bottle cap instead. As a last resort, you can use the carton that your eggs came in. Since this project can get a little messy, it would be a good idea to cover your work surface with some newspaper or a cheap, plastic tablecloth as well.

steps.headline: Get some edible spray paint.
steps.description: This is the same kind of spray paint cake decorators use to decorate their cakes and cupcakes with. It is essentially food coloring, but in spray-on form. You can find it in the cake decorating aisle of an arts and crafts store. You can use just one color for a standard ombre, or two colors for a multicolor ombre. Regular spray paint is not recommended because it is not food safe. If you only have regular spray paint on hand, you must use must use hallow/blown-out eggs.

steps.headline: Lightly spray the top of the egg.
steps.description: Hold the can above the egg, and spray straight down onto the tip. The color will be darker towards the tip of your egg and fade out towards the bottom. It make take a few tries to get this right. If you mess up, you may be able to wash the dye off with water and start again. If you need to, extend the color down the side of the egg, but keep it light.

steps.headline: Let the dye dry.
steps.description: Once the dye dries, you can place the egg into your Easter basket or continue on to the next step for a more colorful egg.

steps.headline: Consider spraying the bottom.
steps.description: This is great if you want a 2-color ombre. Once the paint has dried, flip the egg over, and spray the bottom of the egg using a different color. Let the egg dry completely before placing it into your Easter basket.

steps.headline: Finished.
